Title: Good tools are worth paying for ‚Ä¢ Dylan Fitzgerald
Description: As an industry, we‚Äôve long become accustomed (one might even say spoiled) on the no-cost availability of good tools. Those of us that came up with exposure to Linux, GNU, and the FOSS ecosystem in particular (not to mention the concurrent wave of peer-to-peer file sharing) are likely to have this mindset even more deeply entrenched. Have you ever paid money for a compiler? I have not (at least, that I can recall).

Title: The future of Postgres?
Description:
I‚Äôm often asked what do I think the future for Postgres holds, and my answer has been mostly the same for probably 8 years now, maybe even longer. You see for Postgres itself stability and reliability is core. So where does the new stuff come from if it‚Äôs not in the stable core‚Ä¶ extensions.
Extensions within Postgres are unlike most other databases allowing you to modify or well extend the standard Postgres behavior. You can build other storage backends, new types, etc. Postgres itself ships with a number of extensions within the ‚Äúcontrib‚Äù. The list of contrib extensions hasn‚Äôt changed any time recently, but even contrib is a small sampling of what is possible. Beyond core there is a whole world of extensions, I want dig into just a smalls sampling starting with a few in core‚Ä¶

Title: WordPress, drama, leadership, and the web
Description: The WordPress saga continues. Theo Browne has a great video overview of things up to October 14. Since I last wrote about this there was more back-and-forth between David Heinemeier Hansson (DHH) and Matt Mullenweg. As I‚Äôve mentioned before, I‚Äôm not a fan of DHH, but I agree with his takes on this situation. On October 13, DHH commented on the Advanced Custom Fields (ACF) hijacking. Mullenweg then responded but deleted the post. Mullenweg put a new post up at the same URL which offered a modicum of contrition, but was still doubling down on his actions. DHH then responded with a thoughtful rebuke that didn‚Äôt mention Mullenweg at all.

Title: C# Recursion With File Folder Hierarchies: Beginner's Guide
Description:
Do you struggle with understanding recursion in programming?

For many people, recursion is a bit of a mind-melter. For others, it just seems to click right away.

In university, I felt like recursion was explained in a theoretical way that didn't feel effective -- but fortunately, I had already been writing enough code to see how it works.

What clicked for me? Using hands-on practical examples and seeing it in action. Let's try it out!

Title: There are exactly 8 bits in a byte
Description: C has the CHAR_BIT macro which contains the implementation-defined number of bits in a byte, without restrictions on the value of this number. C++ imports this macro as-is. Many other macros and character traits have values derived from CHAR_BIT. While this was historically relevant in computing‚Äôs early days, modern hardware has overwhelmingly converged on the assumption that a byte is 8 bits. This document proposes that C++ formally mandates that a byte is 8 bits.
